an10.54:1.1.pli: “No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paracittapariyāyakusalo hoti, atha ‘sacittapariyāyakusalo bhavissāmī’ti—
an10.54:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in encompassing another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in encompassing my own mind.’

an10.54:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in encompassing their own mind?

an10.54:2.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanakajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udapatte sakaṃ mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhamāno sace tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tasseva rajassa vā aṅgaṇassa vā pahānāya vāyamati.
an10.54:2.2.eng: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.

an10.54:2.3.pli: No ce tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tenevattamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo:
an10.54:2.3.eng: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for:

an10.54:2.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno paccavekkhaṇā bahukārā hoti kusalesu dhammesu:
an10.54:2.5.eng: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.

an10.54:2.6.pli: ‘lābhī nu khomhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na nu khomhi lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, lābhī nu khomhi adhipaññādhammavipassanāya, na nu khomhi lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti.
an10.54:2.6.eng: ‘Do I have internal serenity of heart or not? Do I have the higher wisdom of discernment of principles or not?’

an10.54:3.1.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an10.54:3.1.eng: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

an10.54:3.2.pli: ‘lābhīmhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ajjhattaṃ cetosamathe patiṭṭhāya adhipaññādhammavipassanāya yogo karaṇīyo.
an10.54:3.2.eng: ‘I have serenity but not discernment.’ Grounded on serenity, they should practice meditation to get discernment.

an10.54:3.3.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa lābhī ca adhipaññādhammavipassanāya.
an10.54:3.3.eng: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

an10.54:4.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an10.54:4.1.eng: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

an10.54:4.2.pli: ‘lābhīmhi adhipaññādhammavipassanāya, na lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā adhipaññādhammavipassanāya patiṭṭhāya ajjhattaṃ cetosamathe yogo karaṇīyo.
an10.54:4.2.eng: ‘I have discernment but not serenity.’ Grounded on discernment, they should practice meditation to get serenity.

an10.54:4.3.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti adhipaññādhammavipassanāya lābhī ca ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa.
an10.54:4.3.eng: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

an10.54:5.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an10.54:5.1.eng: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

an10.54:5.2.pli: ‘na lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.54:5.2.eng: ‘I have neither serenity nor discernment.’ In order to get those skillful qualities, they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an10.54:5.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā.
an10.54:5.3.eng: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an10.54:5.4.pli: Tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya.

an10.54:5.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tena bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.54:5.5.eng: In the same way, in order to get those skillful qualities, that mendicant should apply extraordinary enthusiasm …

an10.54:5.6.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa lābhī ca adhipaññādhammavipassanāya.
an10.54:5.6.eng: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

an10.54:6.1.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
an10.54:6.1.eng: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

an10.54:6.2.pli: ‘lābhīmhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesuyeva kusalesu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya uttari āsavānaṃ khayāya yogo karaṇīyo.
an10.54:6.2.eng: ‘I have both serenity and discernment.’ Grounded on those skillful qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.

an10.54:7.1.eng: I say that there are two kinds of robes:

an10.54:7.2.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.

an10.54:7.3.eng: I say that there are two kinds of almsfood:

an10.54:7.4.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.

an10.54:7.5.eng: I say that there are two kinds of lodging:

an10.54:7.6.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an10.54:7.7.eng: I say that there are two kinds of village or town:

an10.54:7.8.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an10.54:7.9.eng: I say that there are two kinds of country:

an10.54:7.10.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an10.54:7.11.eng: I say that there are two kinds of individual:

an10.54:7.12.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an10.54:8.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of robes:

an10.54:8.2.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

an10.54:8.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:8.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:8.4.eng: Well, should you know of a robe:

an10.54:8.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
an10.54:8.5.eng: ‘When I wear this robe, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not wear that kind of robe.

an10.54:8.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a robe:

an10.54:8.7.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ sevitabbaṃ.
an10.54:8.7.eng: ‘When I wear this robe, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should wear that kind of robe.

an10.54:8.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of robes:

an10.54:8.9.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

an10.54:8.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an10.54:8.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an10.54:9.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of almsfood:

an10.54:9.2.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.’

an10.54:9.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:9.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:9.4.eng: Well, should you know of almsfood:

an10.54:9.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me piṇḍapātaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo piṇḍapāto na sevitabbo.
an10.54:9.5.eng: ‘When I eat this almsfood, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not eat that kind of almsfood.

an10.54:9.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of almsfood:

an10.54:9.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me piṇḍapātaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo piṇḍapāto sevitabbo.
an10.54:9.7.eng: ‘When I eat this almsfood, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should eat that kind of almsfood.

an10.54:9.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of almsfood:

an10.54:9.9.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.’

an10.54:9.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an10.54:9.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an10.54:10.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of lodging:

an10.54:10.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:10.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:10.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:10.4.eng: Well, should you know of a lodging:

an10.54:10.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me senāsanaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṃ senāsanaṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
an10.54:10.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this lodging, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of lodging.

an10.54:10.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a lodging:

an10.54:10.7.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me senāsanaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṃ senāsanaṃ sevitabbaṃ.
an10.54:10.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this lodging, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of lodging.

an10.54:10.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of lodging:

an10.54:10.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:10.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an10.54:10.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an10.54:11.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of village or town:

an10.54:11.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:11.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:11.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:11.4.eng: Well, should you know of a village or town:

an10.54:11.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me gāmanigamaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo gāmanigamo na sevitabbo.
an10.54:11.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this village or town, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of village or town.

an10.54:11.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a village or town:

an10.54:11.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me gāmanigamaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo gāmanigamo sevitabbo.
an10.54:11.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this village or town, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of village or town.

an10.54:11.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of village or town:

an10.54:11.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:11.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an10.54:11.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an10.54:12.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of country:

an10.54:12.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:12.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:12.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:12.4.eng: Well, should you know of a country:

an10.54:12.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me janapadapadesaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo janapadapadeso na sevitabbo.
an10.54:12.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this country, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of country.

an10.54:12.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a country:

an10.54:12.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me janapadapadesaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo janapadapadeso sevitabbo.
an10.54:12.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this country, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of country.

an10.54:12.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of country:

an10.54:12.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:12.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an10.54:12.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an10.54:13.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two two kinds of individual:

an10.54:13.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:13.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an10.54:13.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an10.54:13.4.eng: Well, should you know of an individual:

an10.54:13.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo puggalo na sevitabbo.
an10.54:13.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this individual, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of individual.

an10.54:13.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of an individual:

an10.54:13.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo.
an10.54:13.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this individual, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of individual.

an10.54:13.8.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of individual:

an10.54:13.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an10.54:13.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an10.54:13.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an10.55:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an10.55:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an10.55:2.1.eng: “Reverends, they speak of an individual liable to decline,

an10.55:2.2.eng: and one not liable to decline.

an10.55:2.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, parihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā, kittāvatā ca pana aparihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an10.55:2.3.eng: But how did the Buddha define an individual liable to decline, and one not liable to decline?”

an10.55:2.4.pli: “Dūratopi kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āgacchāma āyasmato sāriputtassa santike etassa bhāsitassa atthamaññātuṃ.
an10.55:2.4.eng: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

an10.55:2.5.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmantaṃyeva sāriputtaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho.
an10.55:2.5.eng: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.

an10.55:2.6.eng: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an10.55:3.1.eng: “Then listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.55:3.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an10.55:4.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, parihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā?
an10.55:4.1.eng: “How did the Buddha define an individual liable to decline?

an10.55:4.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu assutañceva dhammaṃ na suṇāti, sutā cassa dhammā sammosaṃ gacchanti, ye cassa dhammā pubbe cetaso asamphuṭṭhapubbā te cassa na samudācaranti, aviññātañceva na vijānāti.
an10.55:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t get to hear a teaching they haven’t heard before. They forget those teachings they have heard. They don’t keep exercising the teachings with which they are already familiar. And they don’t come to understand what they haven’t understood before.

an10.55:4.3.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, parihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā.
an10.55:4.3.eng: That’s how the Buddha defined an individual liable to decline.

an10.55:5.1.pli: Kittāvatā ca panāvuso, aparihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā?
an10.55:5.1.eng: And how did the Buddha define an individual not liable to decline?

an10.55:5.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu assutañceva dhammaṃ suṇāti, sutā cassa dhammā na sammosaṃ gacchanti, ye cassa dhammā pubbe cetaso asamphuṭṭhapubbā te cassa samudācaranti, aviññātañceva vijānāti.
an10.55:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant gets to hear a teaching they haven’t heard before. They remember those teachings they have heard. They keep exercising the teachings with which they are already familiar. And they come to understand what they haven’t understood before.

an10.55:5.3.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, aparihānadhammo puggalo vutto bhagavatā.
an10.55:5.3.eng: That’s how the Buddha defined an individual not liable to decline.

an10.55:6.1.pli: No ce, āvuso, bhikkhu paracittapariyāyakusalo hoti, atha ‘sacittapariyāyakusalo bhavissāmī’ti—
an10.55:6.1.eng: If a mendicant isn’t skilled in encompassing another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in encompassing my own mind.’

an10.55:7.1.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in encompassing their own mind?

an10.55:7.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanakajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udapatte sakaṃ mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhamāno sace tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tasseva rajassa vā aṅgaṇassa vā pahānāya vāyamati.
an10.55:7.2.eng: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.

an10.55:7.3.pli: No ce tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tenevattamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo:
an10.55:7.3.eng: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for:

an10.55:7.5.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno paccavekkhaṇā bahukārā hoti kusalesu dhammesu:
an10.55:7.5.eng: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.

an10.55:7.6.pli: ‘anabhijjhālu nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, abyāpannacitto nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, vigatathinamiddho nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, anuddhato nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, tiṇṇavicikiccho nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, akkodhano nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, asaṅkiliṭṭhacitto nu kho bahulaṃ viharāmi, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, lābhī nu khomhi ajjhattaṃ dhammapāmojjassa, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, lābhī nu khomhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no, lābhī nu khomhi adhipaññādhammavipassanāya, saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti.
an10.55:7.6.eng: ‘Is contentment often found in me or not? Is kind-heartedness often found in me or not? Is freedom from dullness and drowsiness often found in me or not? Is calm often found in me or not? Is confidence often found in me or not? Is love often found in me or not? Is purity of mind often found in me or not? Is internal joy with the teaching found in me or not? Is internal serenity of heart found in me or not? Is the higher wisdom of discernment of principles found in me or not?’

an10.55:8.1.pli: Sace pana, āvuso, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno sabbepime kusale dhamme attani na samanupassati, tenāvuso, bhikkhunā sabbesaṃyeva imesaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.55:8.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant, while checking, doesn’t see any of these skillful qualities in themselves. In order to get them they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an10.55:8.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā.
an10.55:8.2.eng: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an10.55:8.3.pli: Tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya.

an10.55:8.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, tena bhikkhunā sabbesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.55:8.4.eng: In the same way, they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm to get those skillful qualities …

an10.55:9.1.pli: Sace panāvuso, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno ekacce kusale dhamme attani samanupassati, ekacce kusale dhamme attani na samanupassati, tenāvuso, bhikkhunā ye kusale dhamme attani samanupassati tesu kusalesu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya, ye kusale dhamme attani na samanupassati tesaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.55:9.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant, while checking, sees some of these skillful qualities in themselves, but doesn’t see others. Grounded on the skillful qualities they see, they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness in order to get the skillful qualities they don’t see.

an10.55:9.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā.
an10.55:9.2.eng: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

an10.55:9.3.pli: Tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya.

an10.55:9.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, tena bhikkhunā ye kusale dhamme attani samanupassati tesu kusalesu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya, ye kusale dhamme attani na samanupassati tesaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
an10.55:9.4.eng: In the same way, grounded on the skillful qualities they see, they should apply extraordinary enthusiasm to get those skillful qualities they don’t see.

an10.55:10.1.pli: Sace panāvuso, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno sabbepime kusale dhamme attani samanupassati, tenāvuso, bhikkhunā sabbesveva imesu kusalesu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya uttari āsavānaṃ khayāya yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
an10.55:10.1.eng: But suppose a mendicant, while checking, sees all of these skillful qualities in themselves. Grounded on all these skillful qualities they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”

an10.56:1.1.pli: “Dasayimā, bhikkhave, saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an10.56:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these ten perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.

an10.56:1.3.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—
an10.56:1.3.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.

an10.56:1.4.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, dasa saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā”ti.
an10.56:1.4.eng: These ten perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.”

an10.57:1.1.pli: “Dasayimā, bhikkhave, saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an10.57:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these ten perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.

an10.57:1.3.pli: Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aṭṭhikasaññā, puḷavakasaññā, vinīlakasaññā, vicchiddakasaññā, uddhumātakasaññā—
an10.57:1.3.eng: The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, a skeleton, a worm-infested corpse, a livid corpse, a split open corpse, and a bloated corpse.

an10.57:1.4.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, dasa saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā”ti.
an10.57:1.4.eng: These ten perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.”

an10.58:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an10.58:1.2.pli: ‘kiṃmūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, kiṃsambhavā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamudayā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpamukhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃadhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, kiṃuttarā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsārā sabbe dhammā, kiṃogadhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpariyosānā sabbe dhammā’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ kinti byākareyyāthā”ti?
an10.58:1.2.eng: ‘Reverends, all things have what as their root? What produces them? What is their origin? What is their meeting place? What is their chief? What is their ruler? What is their overseer? What is their core? What is their objective? What is their culmination?’ How would you answer them?”

an10.58:1.3.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an10.58:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an10.58:2.1.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.58:2.1.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.58:2.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an10.58:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an10.58:3.2.pli: ‘kiṃmūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, kiṃsambhavā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamudayā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpamukhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃ adhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, kiṃuttarā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsārā sabbe dhammā, kiṃogadhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpariyosānā sabbe dhammā’ti,
an10.58:3.2.eng: ‘Reverends, all things have what as their root? What produces them? What is their origin? What is their meeting place? What is their chief? What is their ruler? What is their overseer? What is their core? What is their objective? What is their culmination?’

an10.58:3.3.pli: evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

an10.58:3.4.pli: ‘chandamūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, manasikārasambhavā sabbe dhammā, phassasamudayā sabbe dhammā, vedanāsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, samādhippamukhā sabbe dhammā, satādhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, paññuttarā sabbe dhammā, vimuttisārā sabbe dhammā, amatogadhā sabbe dhammā, nibbānapariyosānā sabbe dhammā’ti.
an10.58:3.4.eng: ‘Reverends, all things are rooted in desire. They are produced by application of mind. Contact is their origin. Feeling is their meeting place. Immersion is their chief. Mindfulness is their ruler. Wisdom is their overseer. Freedom is their core. Their objective is freedom from death. And extinguishment is their culmination.’

an10.58:3.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
an10.58:3.5.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

an10.59:1.2.pli: ‘yathāpabbajjāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, na cuppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassanti;
an10.59:1.2.eng: ‘Our minds will be consolidated as they were when we went forth, and arisen bad unskillful qualities will not occupy our minds.

an10.59:1.3.pli: aniccasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, anattasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, asubhasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, ādīnavasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, lokassa samañca visamañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, lokassa bhavañca vibhavañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, lokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, pahānasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, virāgasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissati, nirodhasaññāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissatī’ti—
an10.59:1.3.eng: Our minds will be consolidated in the perceptions of impermanence, not-self, ugliness, and drawbacks. Knowing what is fair and unfair in the world, our minds will be consolidated in that perception. Knowing  existence and nonexistence in the world, our minds will be consolidated in that perception. Knowing the origin and disappearance of the world, our minds will be consolidated in that perception. Our minds will be consolidated in the perceptions of giving up, fading away, and cessation.’

an10.59:2.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno yathāpabbajjāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti na cuppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, aniccasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, anattasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, asubhasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, ādīnavasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, lokassa samañca visamañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, lokassa bhavañca vibhavañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, lokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca ñatvā taṃsaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, pahānasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, virāgasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, nirodhasaññāparicitañca cittaṃ hoti, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
an10.59:2.1.eng: When your minds are consolidated in these ten perceptions, you can expect one of two results:

an10.59:2.2.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
an10.59:2.2.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

an10.6:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.6:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.6:1.2.pli: “siyā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an10.6:1.2.eng: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. And they wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And yet they would still perceive.”

an10.6:1.3.pli: “Siyā, ānanda, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an10.6:1.3.eng: “It could be, Ānanda, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. And they wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And yet they would still perceive.”

an10.6:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an10.6:3.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an10.6:3.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an10.6:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an10.6:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. And they wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And yet they would still perceive.”
